content:
If I understand correctly, an adjunction between two functors F and G would be isomorphisms between Hom(FX,Y) and Hom(X,GY) for all X,Y (which is also natural).

I was wondering if these isomorphisms are unique? Playing around, the isomorphisms seem to be unique. I was wondering if this is a theorem?
It should be fun to find the smallest counterexample! Can we do it when F and G are the identity functor on a category with one object?

Indeed, if we take the category with one object xxx, and two morphisms hom(x,x)={id,f}hom(x, x) = \{id, f\}hom(x,x)={id,f} with f≠idf \neq idf=id and f2=idf^2 = idf2=id, then I think we have two distinct bijections hom(x,x)≅hom(x,x)hom(x, x) \cong hom(x, x)hom(x,x)≅hom(x,x) natural in xxx in both positions (covariant, and contravariant).

image.png

@Peva Blanchard - if we take an arbitrary groupoid with one object xxx, so that hom(x,x)\mathrm{hom}(x,x)hom(x,x) is an arbitrary group, is it true that we get one bijection hom(x,x)≅hom(x,x)\mathrm{hom}(x,x) \cong \mathrm{hom}(x,x)hom(x,x)≅hom(x,x), natural in xxx in both positions, from each element of the center of this group?

I think in fact the center of the group is isomorphic to the group of such doubly-natural bijections. We can see this with end calculus: for any category CCC, the Yoneda lemma says

SetCop×C(hom⁡,hom⁡)=∫x,y∈CSet(hom⁡(x,y),hom⁡(x,y))≅∫x∈Chom⁡(x,x)=CC(IdC,IdC)\begin{align*} \mathrm{Set}^{C^{\mathrm{op}}\times C}(\hom,\hom) &= \int_{x,y\in C} \mathrm{Set}(\hom(x,y),\hom(x,y)) \\ &\cong \int_{x\in C} \hom(x,x)\\ & = C^C (\mathrm{Id}_C,\mathrm{Id}_C) \end{align*}SetCop×C(hom,hom)​=∫x,y∈C​Set(hom(x,y),hom(x,y))≅∫x∈C​hom(x,x)=CC(IdC​,IdC​)​

and the latter is the [[center of a category]], which is so-named because the center of a one-object groupoid is the center of the corresponding group.

Mike Shulman said:

We can see this with end calculus: for any category CCC, the Yoneda lemma says

SetCop×C(hom⁡,hom⁡)=∫x,y∈CSet(hom⁡(x,y),hom⁡(x,y))≅∫x∈Chom⁡(x,x)=CC(IdC,IdC)\begin{align*} \mathrm{Set}^{C^{\mathrm{op}}\times C}(\hom,\hom) &= \int_{x,y\in C} \mathrm{Set}(\hom(x,y),\hom(x,y)) \\ &\cong \int_{x\in C} \hom(x,x)\\ & = C^C (\mathrm{Id}_C,\mathrm{Id}_C) \end{align*}SetCop×C(hom,hom)​=∫x,y∈C​Set(hom(x,y),hom(x,y))≅∫x∈C​hom(x,x)=CC(IdC​,IdC​)​

Nice! The calculation could also be used to further answer @Suraaj K S's question by using the following generalizations:

  1. choosing one direction of the isomorphism gives us a unit:
    SetCop×D(hom(F(−),−),hom(−,G(−)))≅CC(idC,GF)\mathbf{Set}^{C^{\mathsf{op}}\times D}(\mathsf{hom}(F(-),-),\mathsf{hom}(-,G(-))) \cong C^C(\mathsf{id}_C,GF)SetCop×D(hom(F(−),−),hom(−,G(−)))≅CC(idC​,GF)

  2. choosing the other direction of the isomorphism gives us a counit:
    SetCop×D(hom(−,G(−)),hom(F(−),−))≅DD(FG,idD)\mathbf{Set}^{C^{\mathsf{op}}\times D}(\mathsf{hom}(-,G(-)),\mathsf{hom}(F(-),-)) \cong D^D(FG,\mathsf{id}_D)SetCop×D(hom(−,G(−)),hom(F(−),−))≅DD(FG,idD​)

Using the previous isomorphisms, we can say that given (F,G)(F,G)(F,G) and a pair of units/counits, there is a unique way to choose the natural bijections hom(F(−),−)↔hom(−,G(−))\mathsf{hom}(F(-),-)\leftrightarrow \mathsf{hom}(-,G(-))hom(F(−),−)↔hom(−,G(−)).

I have not checked the details, but is true that the two isomorphisms in the case hom(x,x)={id,f}\mathsf{hom}(x,x) = \{\mathsf{id},f\}hom(x,x)={id,f} gives us the pairs (f,f)(f,f)(f,f) and (id,id)(\mathsf{id},\mathsf{id})(id,id) for the different possible unit/counit pairs?

This is interesting. But, I think we cannot choose options 1 and 2 independently: the unit and counit must satisfy the zig-zag identities.

It's not a complete argument, but in the example of hom(x,x)={id,f}hom(x, x) = \{id, f\}hom(x,x)={id,f}, I think this rules out the choices (id,f)(id, f)(id,f) and (f,id)(f, id)(f,id).

Peva Blanchard said:

This is interesting. But, I think we cannot choose options 1 and 2 independently: the unit and counit must satisfy the zig-zag identities.

Oh yeah, I definitely agree
And as you said, it is interesting because now we can explore more general situations like weak retractions (e.g. only id⇒GF\mathsf{id} \Rightarrow GFid⇒GF is given), etc.

Peva Blanchard said:

It's not a complete argument, but in the example of hom(x,x)={id,f}hom(x, x) = \{id, f\}hom(x,x)={id,f}, I think this rules out the choices (id,f)(id, f)(id,f) and (f,id)(f, id)(f,id).

Hmm, I see. So, I think we have the following natural inclusions:

SetCop×D(hom(F(−),−),hom(−,G(−))↪RelCop×D(hom(F(−),−),hom(−,G(−))\mathbf{Set}^{C^{\mathsf{op}} \times D}(\mathsf{hom}(F(-),-),\mathsf{hom}(-,G(-)) \hookrightarrow \mathbf{Rel}^{C^{\mathsf{op}} \times D}(\mathsf{hom}(F(-),-),\mathsf{hom}(-,G(-))SetCop×D(hom(F(−),−),hom(−,G(−))↪RelCop×D(hom(F(−),−),hom(−,G(−))

SetCop×D(hom(−,G(−),hom(F(−),−))↪RelCop×D(hom(−,G(−),hom(F(−),−))\mathbf{Set}^{C^{\mathsf{op}} \times D}(\mathsf{hom}(-,G(-),\mathsf{hom}(F(-),-)) \hookrightarrow \mathbf{Rel}^{C^{\mathsf{op}} \times D}(\mathsf{hom}(-,G(-),\mathsf{hom}(F(-),-))SetCop×D(hom(−,G(−),hom(F(−),−))↪RelCop×D(hom(−,G(−),hom(F(−),−))

and a natural isomorphism:

RelCop×D(hom(F(−),−),hom(−,G(−))≅RelCop×D(hom(−,G(−),hom(F(−),−))\mathbf{Rel}^{C^{\mathsf{op}} \times D}(\mathsf{hom}(F(-),-),\mathsf{hom}(-,G(-)) \cong \mathbf{Rel}^{C^{\mathsf{op}} \times D}(\mathsf{hom}(-,G(-),\mathsf{hom}(F(-),-))RelCop×D(hom(F(−),−),hom(−,G(−))≅RelCop×D(hom(−,G(−),hom(F(−),−))

My guess is that the pullback of the previous two inclusions (up to the isomorphism) gives us the homset of natural bijections we are after:

BijCop×D(hom(F(−),−),hom(−,G(−))\mathbf{Bij}^{C^{\mathsf{op}} \times D}(\mathsf{hom}(F(-),-),\mathsf{hom}(-,G(-))BijCop×D(hom(F(−),−),hom(−,G(−))

The relations involved in the construction of this pullback probably determines (to some large extent) the relationship between the unit and counit.
However, not sure yet how we can use that pullback to formalize that relationship
